ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:0.2_0: The monks’ rules and their analysis
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:0.5_0: 6. The training rule on asking non-relations
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.2_0: At that time Venerable Upananda was giving teachings to give a Dhamma talk.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.3_0: On one occasion the son of a prominent merchant approached Upananda,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.4_0: And Upananda instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.5_0: Afterwards that merchant’s son said to Upananda:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.7_0: I’m able to give robes, almsfood, a dwelling, and medicines.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.8_0: the same thing to that merchant’s son,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.9_0: “It’s shameful for the son of a good family to walk around in only one wrap.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.10_0: Please wait until I get back home.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.11_0: I’ll send you this wrap or a better one.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.13_0: the same thing to that merchant’s son,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.14_0: and he got the same reply.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.15_0: and a third time Upananda said
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.16_0: the same thing to that merchant’s son,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.17_0: and he got the same reply.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.18_0: They then said, “Why do you give an invitation if you don’t wish to give?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.1.19_0: Being pressured by Upananda, that merchant’s son gave him one of his wraps and left.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.1_0: People asked him, “Why are you walking around in only one wrap?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.2_0: And he told them what had happened.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.3_0: People then complained and criticized those nuns,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.4_0: “These Sakyan ascetics have great desires; they’re not content.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.5_0: Even to make them an appropriate offer isn’t easy.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.6_0: How can they take his wrap when the merchant’s son was making an appropriate offer?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.7_0: The monks heard those people complaining,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.8_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.9_0: “How can Venerable Upananda ask the merchant’s son for a robe?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.10_0: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.11_0: “Is it true, Upananda, that you acted like this?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.15_0: “Foolish man, people who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.16_0: And still you asked the merchant’s son for a robe.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.17_0: Foolish man, this won’t give rise to confidence in those without it ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.18_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.19.1_0: ‘If a monk asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:1.2.20_0: The Buddha has laid down a training rule for the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.1_0: On one occasion a number of monks were traveling from Sāketa to Sāvatthī.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.1_1: As they were traveling, they were attacked by gangsters.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.2_0: Knowing that the Buddha had laid down this training rule and being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not ask for robes.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.3_0: They walked naked to Sāvatthī and bowed down to the monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.4_0: The monks said, “These Ājīvaka ascetics are good people, in that they bow down to the monks.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.6_0: And the monks said to Venerable Upāli, “Upāli, please examine them.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.7_0: The naked monks then told Upāli what had happened, and he told the monks, “They are monks.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.7_1: And Upāli said to those monks, “Upāli, these monks are misbehaving.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.8_0: The monks of few desires complained and criticized Devadatta,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.10_0: Shouldn’t they have covered up with grass and leaves?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.11_0: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.12_0: who gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.13_0: “Monks, if a monk’s robes are stolen or destroyed, I allow him to ask an unrelated householder for robes.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.14_0: At the first monastery where he arrives, if the Sangha has a monastery robe, a bedspread, a floor cover, or a mattress cover, he should take that and put it on, thinking, ‘When I get a robe, I’ll return it.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.15_0: If there’s none of these things, he should cover up with grass and leaves before going on. He should not go on while naked.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.15_1: should not go on a naked monk’s head.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.16_0: If he does, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.17_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.18.1_0: ‘If a monk asks an unrelated male or female householder for a robe, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:2.19_0: These are the appropriate occasions: his robes are stolen or his robes are destroyed.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.2_0: and you have the same kind of perception ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.4_0: ... The monks who have been given the full ordination in unanimity by both Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.6_0: ’s mother’s side, of pure descent, irrefutable and impeccable in questions of ancestry back to the seventh paternal generation.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.12_0: one of the six kinds of robes that is transferred to another.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.16_0: a monk’s robe is taken by kings, bandits, scoundrels, or anyone whomsoever.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.1.18_0: a monk’s robe is burnt by fire, carried away by water, eaten by rats or termites, or worn through use.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.1_0: If he asks, except on an appropriate occasion, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.2_0: When he gets the sitting-blanket, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.3_0: It should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.4_0: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.6_0: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth which I received after asking an unrelated householder, but not on an appropriate occasion, is to be relinquished.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.7_0: I relinquish them to the Sangha.’ ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.2.10_0: ‘I give these tonics back to you.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.1_0: If the person is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and he asks them for a robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.2_0: If the person is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and he asks them for a robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.3_0: If the person is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and he asks them for a robe-cloth, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.4_0: If the person is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.5_0: If the person is related, but the monk is unsure of it, commits an offense of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.3.6_0: If the householders are related and he perceives them as such, there is no offense.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.4_0: if he asks those who have given an invitation;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.5_0: if he asks for the benefit of someone else;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.6_0: if it is by means of one’s own property;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np6:3.4.9_0: The sixth rule, the training rule on asking non-relations, is finished.
